text.p: These are the leading stories in the Skopje press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Macedonian government proposed a new law for compensating depositors of TAT, Alfa S and Lavci savings houses. Every household to receive 500 German marks over the next six months until bankruptcy proceedings end and will claim the rest from the bankruptcy estate.
- Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov appointed Vlado Popovski as director of the Macedonian intelligence agency. Popovski, currently justice minister, was defence minister in former government.
- Parliament passed a radio broadcasting law, under which Macedonian radio and television subscirption will be included in the electricity bills.

- Deputy Prime Ministers Jane Miljovski and Ljube Trpeski, Education Minister Sofija Todorova, and Foreign Minister Ljubomir Frckoski could go in the government reshuffle expected after Easter holidays.
- Owner of TAT savings society Sonja Nikolovska was released from custody on bail of one million German marks. -- Mircela Casule, Skopje newsroom +389 91 201 196
